choices.text: Increased size of germinal centres of spleen
Decreased size of paracortical areas of lymph node
Increased antibody production by plasma cells
Increased bone marrow production of lymphocytes

questions.text: A 3-day-old male infant, weighing 2.5 kg, was diagnosed with congenital myasthenic syndrome, presenting with significant respiratory distress due to poor respiratory muscle function. The diagnosis was confirmed through clinical examination and electrodiagnostic studies. The baby was planned for neonatal thymectomy as part of the management strategy. Neonatal thymectomy results in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neonatal thymectomy results in a decreased size of the paracortical areas of the lymph node.
  • The thymus is a lymphoid organ situated in the neck that produces T-lymphocytes for the immune system.
  • The paracortical area of a lymph node, which surrounds the lymphoid follicles in the cortex, is mainly made up of T cells.
  • Therefore, due to thymectomy, there is a decreased production of T cells, leading to a decreased size of these T-cell rich paracortical areas.
  • While neonatal thymectomy can be life-saving for specific neuromuscular disorders, it carries risks such as infection and long-term immune system implications, necessitating multidisciplinary follow-up.

Explanation of Other Options:

Increased size of germinal centres of spleen (Option A): Germinal centers are sites where B cells proliferate and differentiate, and they require T cell help for proper function. If T cell numbers decrease due to thymectomy, this would likely lead to a decreased germinal center size, not an increase.

Increased antibody production by plasma cells (Option C): With a decrease in T cells, particularly helper T cells, there would be reduced stimulation of B cells. This would consequently lead to decreased antibody production rather than an increase.

Increased bone marrow production of lymphocytes (Option D): This is not a direct result of thymectomy. The bone marrow produces lymphocytes independently of the thymus, and thymectomy primarily impacts the maturation and peripheral distribution of T cells, not their bone marrow production.

Key Takeaway:

Neonatal thymectomy impairs T-lymphocyte production, leading to a decreased size of T-cell rich areas, specifically the paracortical areas of lymph nodes.

questions.text: T-cell dependent region in lymph node:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The paracortical area is the T-cell dependent region in a lymph node. This broad, ill-defined intermediate zone between the cortical follicles and medullary cords predominantly contains T lymphocytes and interdigitating cells.
  • Lymph nodes are organized into an outer cortex and an inner medulla.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Cortex: The cortex contains accumulations of lymphocytes (primary lymphoid follicles), within which germinal centers (secondary follicles) develop during antigenic stimulation.
  • Medulla: In the medulla, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages are arranged as elongated branching bands (medullary cords). The cortical follicles and medullary cords primarily contain B lymphocytes and constitute the bursa-dependent areas.
  • Mantle layer: The mantle layer refers to the region of naive B cells surrounding the germinal center within a lymphoid follicle.

Key Takeaway: The paracortical area of a lymph node is the T-cell rich region, essential for T-lymphocyte activity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain in the left upper quadrant, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and lightheadedness. On examination, tenderness in the left upper quadrant and signs of splenic enlargement (splenomegaly) were noted. Vital signs indicated mild hypotension and tachycardia. An ultrasound revealed an enlarged spleen with a suspected hematoma, and a CT scan confirmed a splenic rupture with intra-abdominal bleeding. The patient was scheduled for a splenectomy. Most common infections after splenectomy result from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is undergoing a splenectomy due to splenic rupture. The spleen is the largest secondary lymphoid organ and plays a crucial role in the immune response, particularly against bloodborne antigens, and acts as a systemic filter for trapping circulating foreign particles.
  • Most common infections after splenectomy result from capsulated bacteria. The spleen is essential for clearing encapsulated bacteria from the bloodstream. Therefore, patients who have undergone splenectomy are at significantly increased risk of severe infections, especially pneumococcal infection caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is an encapsulated organism. Vaccination against encapsulated organisms is critical for post-splenectomy patients to prevent these infections.
  • Encapsulated bacteria include (mnemonic: Yes Some Killer Bacteria Have Pretty Nice Capsule):
    • Yersinia pestis
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae
    • Klebsiella pneumoniae
    • Bacillus anthracis
    • Haemophilus influenzae
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa
    • Neisseria meningitidis
    • Cryptococcus Neoformans
  • Overwhelming post-splenectomy infections (OPSI) can be seen even 2-3 years after the procedure.

Explanation of Other Options:

Non-capsulated bacteria (Option B): While infections with non-capsulated bacteria can occur, the spleen's primary role in clearing encapsulated bacteria means that these are the predominant pathogens causing severe post-splenectomy infections.

Gram positive bacteria (Option C): This is a broad category. While Streptococcus pneumoniae (a Gram-positive bacterium) is a common cause of post-splenectomy infections, it is specifically its capsule that makes it a significant threat in asplenic individuals, rather than just its Gram staining property.

Gram Negative bacteria (Option D): This is also a broad category. While some Gram-negative bacteria are encapsulated (e.g., Klebsiella pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Neisseria meningitidis) and thus pose a risk, the key factor for increased susceptibility post-splenectomy is the capsule, not just the Gram stain characteristic.

Key Takeaway:

The spleen is crucial for clearing encapsulated bacteria, making capsulated bacteria the most common cause of severe infections after splenectomy, notably Streptococcus pneumoniae.

questions.text: All of the following are part of innate immunity except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • T cells are not part of innate immunity. T cells are components of acquired or adaptive immunity.
  • Acquired immunity is the resistance an individual gains during life by recognizing and selectively eliminating specific foreign molecules.
  • It displays characteristic features such as antigen specificity, diversity, immunologic memory, and self/nonself recognition. T-cells are specifically involved in cell-mediated immunity.
  • In contrast, innate immunity provides the first line of defense against infections. It is the resistance an individual possesses due to their genetic and constitutional make-up, and it is not affected by prior contact with microorganisms or immunization. Innate immunity can be considered at the level of the species, race, or individual.

Key Takeaway:

T cells are part of the acquired (adaptive) immune system, which is characterized by specificity and memory, while Complement, NK cells, and Macrophages are components of the innate immune system, providing the immediate, non-specific first line of defense.

questions.text: Lysozyme is present in the following secretions of the body except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • CSF is the secretion in which lysozyme is not typically present. Lysozyme is a natural antimicrobial enzyme that forms part of the innate immune system.
  • Lysozyme is present in various body secretions, including:
    • Tears (Lacrimal secretions).
    • Saliva.
    • Human breast milk.
    • Respiratory mucus secretions.
  • Beyond secretions, lysozyme is also found in the cytoplasmic granules of macrophages and polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs).
  • Clinical significance:
    • Reduced lysozyme levels have been associated with bronchopulmonary dysplasia in newborns.
    • In certain cancers (especially myelomonocytic leukemia), excessive production of lysozyme by cancer cells can lead to toxic levels in the blood, potentially causing kidney failure and low blood potassium.
    • It is used as a marker for sarcoidosis disease activity and is suitable for disease monitoring (sensitive but less specific).

Explanation of Other Options:

Lacrimal secretions (Option A): Lysozyme is present in tears, which are lacrimal secretions, providing an important defense mechanism for the eyes.

Saliva (Option C): Lysozyme is present in saliva, contributing to the antimicrobial properties of the oral cavity.

Respiratory tract secretions (Option D): Lysozyme is present in respiratory mucus secretions, playing a role in protecting the respiratory tract from pathogens.

Key Takeaway:

Lysozyme is an antimicrobial enzyme found in tears, saliva, human breast milk, and respiratory secretions, as well as in specific immune cells, but not typically in CSF.

questions.text: All of the following are Negative acute phase reactants except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • C-reactive protein (CRP) is not a negative acute phase reactant; instead, it is a positive acute-phase protein.
  • Acute phase reactants are inflammation markers that exhibit significant changes in serum concentration during inflammation.
  • CRP is of hepatic origin and its levels increase following interleukin-6 secretion by macrophages, adipocytes, and T cells.
  • The plasma half-life of CRP is 19 hours, which is constant across all medical conditions, meaning its blood level is solely affected by its rate of production.

Key Takeaway:

C-reactive protein (CRP) is a positive acute phase reactant whose levels increase during inflammation, while albumin, transferrin, and iron are negative acute phase reactants whose levels typically decrease during inflammation.

choices.text: C2 and C4 normal, C3 is decreased
C3 normal and C2, C4 decreased
C2, C4, C3 all are elevated

questions.text: Which of the following best represents classical complement pathway activation in immuno-inflammatory condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Classical complement pathway activation in immuno-inflammatory conditions is best represented by a decrease in C2, C4, and C3.
  • In such conditions, complement components are actively utilized as part of the immune response.
  • This consumption leads to their decreased levels in the serum. The classical pathway typically involves C1, followed by C4, then C2, which together form the C3 convertase, leading to the cleavage and consumption of C3.
  • Therefore, active pathway utilization results in a reduction of these key components.

Key Takeaway:

Classical complement pathway activation in immuno-inflammatory conditions leads to the consumption and thus decreased levels of its components, notably C2, C4, and C3.

questions.text: Which of the following can act as opsonin?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • C3b can act as an opsonin. Opsonins are extracellular proteins that, when bound to substances or cells, induce phagocytes to engulf those substances or cells. Opsonins act as bridging molecules, bringing the target and the phagocyte into contact and then usually activating the phagocytic receptor to induce engulfment. Other molecules that act as opsonins include C4b and C1q.

Explanation of Other Options:

C3a (Option A): C3a is a chemoattractant and an anaphylatoxin, not an opsonin.

C5a (Option C): C5a is also a chemoattractant and an anaphylatoxin, not an opsonin.

C5-C9 complex (Option D): The C5-C9 complex forms the Membrane Attack Complex (MAC), which is an important immune effector of the complement terminal pathway, composed of complement components C5b, C6, C7, C8, and C9. It mediates cell lysis, rather than acting as an opsonin.

Key Takeaway:

Opsonins are extracellular proteins that enhance phagocytosis by binding to targets, making them more readily engulfed by phagocytes; C3b, C4b, and C1q are examples of opsonins.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. He has a history of recurrent infections, particularly with encapsulated bacteria. Laboratory tests reveal a deficiency in complement components C5-C9. Which of the following pathogens is this patient particularly susceptible to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status suggests meningitis. His history of recurrent encapsulated bacterial infections and a specific deficiency in complement components C5-C9 are crucial diagnostic clues.
  • Deficiency in complement components C5-C9 impairs the formation of the Membrane Attack Complex (MAC). The MAC is essential for directly lysing certain bacteria, particularly those with thin peptidoglycan layers like Gram-negative cocci.
  • Patients with C5-C9 deficiencies are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which can cause meningococcal meningitis. This increased susceptibility is due to the inability to form an effective MAC, which is critical for killing Neisseria.

Explanation of Other Options:

Listeria (Option B): Listeria monocytogenes is a non-sporing, non-capsulated bacterium that causes serious infections primarily in immunocompromised individuals. Susceptibility to Listeria is more commonly associated with defects in cell-mediated immunity (T-cell function) rather than complement deficiencies.

Pseudomonas (Option C): Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause infections in individuals with compromised immune systems. While complement can contribute to the opsonization of Pseudomonas, it is not specifically associated with C5-C9 deficiency as the primary increased susceptibility. Pseudomonas infections are more common in settings with neutrophil dysfunction or other immune deficiencies.

All of the above (Option D): Since Listeria and Pseudomonas are not primarily associated with C5-C9 deficiency in the same critical way as Neisseria, this option is incorrect.

Key Takeaway:

Deficiency in complement components C5-C9 specifically impairs the formation of the Membrane Attack Complex (MAC), leading to a significantly increased susceptibility to Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which relies heavily on MAC-mediated lysis for clearance.

choices.text: Skin test with purified protein derivative

questions.text: Phagocytic function is assessed by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Phagocytic function is primarily assessed by the Nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) . This test evaluates the ability of phagocytes, such as neutrophils and macrophages, to ingest and destroy pathogens.
  • The NBT test is a blood test that measures the immune system's capacity to convert colorless nitroblue tetrazolium to a deep blue color.
  • This conversion indicates the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are essential for bacterial killing by phagocytes.
  • The NBT test is commonly performed as a screen for Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).
  • In individuals with CGD, due to an NADPH oxidase defect, their white cells will not turn blue when exposed to NBT, as they are unable to produce the necessary reactive oxygen species. A higher blue score in the test indicates better production of reactive oxygen species.

Explanation of Other Options:

Proliferative response to mitogen (Option A): This test assesses lymphocyte proliferation, not phagocytic function.

Serum Immunoglobulin assay (Option C): This test measures antibody levels, and is not a direct assessment of phagocytosis.

Skin test with purified protein derivative (Option D): This test assesses cell-mediated immunity, particularly in the context of tuberculosis, rather than phagocytic function.

Key Takeaway:

The Nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test is the primary method for assessing phagocytic function, specifically by measuring the production of reactive oxygen species crucial for bacterial killing, and is used to screen for Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a Macrophage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lymphocytes are not macrophages. Lymphocytes are a distinct type of white blood cell primarily involved in the adaptive immune response.
  • Macrophages, in contrast, originate from blood monocytes that leave the circulation to differentiate in various tissues.
  • Macrophages exhibit substantial heterogeneity, reflected in their morphology, pathogen recognition capabilities, and the levels of inflammatory cytokines (such as IL-1, IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor alpha) they produce.
  • They also produce reactive oxygen species, like nitric oxide, to kill phagocytosed bacteria.
  • This heterogeneity is likely inherited from their monocyte precursors. Macrophages migrate to and circulate within almost every tissue, where they patrol for pathogens and eliminate dead cells.

Explanation of Other Options:

Monocyte (Option A): Monocytes are the circulating precursors that differentiate into macrophages once they enter tissues, making them closely related to macrophages.

Microglia (Option B): Microglia are a specific type of macrophage found as resident immune cells in the central nervous system.

Kupffer cells (Option C): Kupffer cells are a specific type of macrophage found as resident immune cells in the liver.

Key Takeaway:

Lymphocytes are distinct white blood cells involved in adaptive immunity, whereas monocytes, microglia, and Kupffer cells are all types of macrophages or macrophage-derived cells, which are primarily involved in innate immune functions like patrolling, phagocytosis, and cytokine production.

questions.text: Apart from B cells, and T cells, there is another distinct type of lymphocyte known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Besides B cells and T cells, another distinct type of lymphocyte is the Natural Killer (NK) cell. These are also known as Null cells and are large granular lymphocytes.
  • NK cells constitute 5-10% of circulating lymphocytes and lack the characteristic features of either T or B cells.
  • Specifically, they are absent of Pan-T cell markers (like CD-3) and TCR, and do not require the thymus for development.
  • They also lack Pan-B cell markers (like CD-19) and surface immunoglobulins IgM and IgD. Instead, NK cells are characterized by the presence of CD16+, CD56+, and CD94 on their surface.

Explanation of Other Options:

Microglia (Option A): Microglia are specialized macrophages located in the central nervous system (CNS). They act as the primary immune defense in the CNS, constantly monitoring the environment for pathogens and damaged cells. While they have immune functions, they are not classified as lymphocytes.

Macrophage (Option C): Macrophages are large phagocytic cells that originate from monocytes. They are crucial for both innate and adaptive immune responses, engulfing and digesting pathogens, presenting antigens to T cells, and secreting various cytokines. Macrophages are not classified as lymphocytes.

Neutrophil (Option D): Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that are part of the innate immune system. They are the most abundant leukocyte and are often first responders to infection or inflammation, primarily functioning by phagocytosing bacteria and fungi and releasing enzymes and reactive oxygen species. Neutrophils are not classified as lymphocytes.

Key Takeaway:

Beyond B and T cells, Natural Killer (NK) cells are the third distinct type of lymphocyte, characterized by their granular morphology and specific surface markers (CD16+, CD56+, CD94) while lacking typical T and B cell markers.

questions.text: NK cells provide direct immunity against which of the following microorganisms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • NK cells (Natural Killer cells) provide direct immunity primarily against viruses.
  • Their main functions include killing virus-infected cells and cancer cells.
  • NK cells are "natural" because:
    • They are active without prior exposure to the virus.
    • Their activity is not enhanced by exposure.
    • They are not specific for any particular virus.
  • Null cells are large granular lymphocytes.
  • IL-2 produced by macrophages, and interferons alpha and beta produced by virus-infected cells, act as growth factors for NK cells.
  • Killing by NK cells is non-specific and does not rely on antigen presentation by MHC-I/II proteins.
  • They recognize and kill virus-infected cells and tumor cells that have reduced amounts of Class I MHC proteins on their surface. Cells displaying sufficient Class I MHC proteins are not killed.
  • NK cells also detect MICA protein, present on cancer cells but not normal cells, triggering cytotoxin production and tumor cell death upon interaction.
  • NK cells can kill without antibody, but antibody (IgG) enhances their effectiveness: Antibody-Dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC).
  • NK cells kill by secreting cytotoxins (perforins and granzyme), similar to Cytotoxic T cells, and by participating in Fas-Fas ligand-mediated apoptosis.
  • They also produce gamma interferon, which activates macrophages to kill ingested bacteria.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bacteria (Option B): While NK cells indirectly contribute to antibacterial immunity by activating macrophages, they are not primarily responsible for direct immunity against bacteria.

Fungus (Option C): NK cells are not the primary direct responders against fungal infections; other immune cells like phagocytes are better suited for this role.

Chlamydia (Option D): Chlamydia is an obligate intracellular bacterium. While Chlamydia-infected cells might have altered MHC-I expression, T cells and phagocytic cells (like macrophages) are more crucial for controlling such intracellular infections.

Key Takeaway:

NK cells are crucial for direct innate immunity against viruses and cancer cells by recognizing and eliminating host cells with altered or reduced MHC Class I expression, and by secreting cytotoxic molecules and activating other immune cells.

questions.text: NK cells and cytotoxic cells are differentiated by?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

NK cells and cytotoxic T cells are differentiated by the presence of a receptor for IgG.

  • Cytotoxic T cells (CTLs) do not have receptors for antibodies.
  • In contrast, NK cells can express CD16, which binds to the Fc region of IgG antibodies.
  • This binding allows NK cells to mediate Antibody-Dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC), a mechanism where they kill antibody-coated target cells.
  • Natural killer (NK) have azurophilic granules in their cytoplasm that have spontaneous cytotoxicity against a variety of tumor cells, virus-infected cells, and some normal cells in the bone marrow and thymus. These azurophilic granules contain peptides like MPO, α-defensins, bactericidal/permeability-increasing protein (BPI), elastase, proteinase-3, and cathepsin G, which confer potent antimicrobial activity through both oxidative and nonoxidative pathways.
  • NK cell activity is augmented by interferons. IL-2 produced by macrophages, and interferons alpha and beta produced by virus-infected cells, act as growth factors and potent stimulators of NK cells.
  • Their cytotoxicity is typically not antibody-dependent or MHC-restricted in their primary killing mechanism.

Explanation of Other Options:

Interferons reduce NK cell activity (Option A): NK cell activity is augmented by interferons, not reduced.

Antibody specificity (Option B): Antibody specificity is a characteristic of B cells and the antibodies they produce, or how T cells might recognize antigen in an antibody-dependent manner (e.g., in some ADCC scenarios indirectly), but it does not differentiate NK cells from cytotoxic T cells. Cytotoxic T cells recognize specific antigens presented on MHC, not directly antibodies.

Presence in spleen (Option D): Both NK cells and cytotoxic T cells can be found in the spleen, so their presence in this organ does not serve as a distinguishing factor between them.

Key Takeaway:

The key differentiating factor between NK cells and cytotoxic T cells is the presence of an Fc receptor for IgG (CD16) on NK cells, enabling them to mediate Antibody-Dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC), a function absent in cytotoxic T cells

questions.text: Identify the cell shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanationr:

  • The image depicts a large granular lymphocyte (LGL), which is characteristic of an NK cell (Natural Killer cell).
  • Large granular lymphocytes (LGL) are defined as nonadherent mononuclear cells with cytoplasmic azurophilic granules, avid receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, and cytotoxic functions (NK or ADCC activities).
  • NK cells, also known as Null cells, constitute 5-10% of circulating lymphocytes and lack features of either T or B cells.
  • They are identifiable by the absence of Pan-T cell markers (CD-3) and TCR, and they do not require the thymus for development.
  • They also lack Pan-B cell markers (CD-19) and surface IgM, IgD.
  • Key surface markers for NK cells include CD16+ and CD56+, and also CD94.
  • The presence of prominent cytoplasmic granules, as suggested by the typical appearance of an LGL, is a distinguishing feature of NK cells.

Explanation of Other Options:

Plasma cells (Option A): Plasma cells are large, oval-shaped cells with a prominent nucleus and abundant cytoplasm filled with rough endoplasmic reticulum, responsible for producing antibodies. They do not typically contain prominent azurophilic granules like NK cells.

T cells (Option C): T cells are a type of lymphocyte, generally smaller than plasma cells, with a large nucleus and various surface receptors including the T-cell receptor (TCR). T cells do not typically contain prominent azurophilic granules that characterize NK cells.

B cells (Option D): B cells do not typically contain granules. They are lymphocytes primarily involved in humoral immunity.

Key Takeaway:

The presence of large cytoplasmic azurophilic granules is a key morphological feature that distinguishes Natural Killer (NK) cells from other lymphocytes like T cells and B cells, as well as from plasma cells.

questions.text: Active immunity is NOT acquired by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Active immunity is NOT acquired by immunoglobulin transfer.
  • Active immunity is the resistance developed by an individual as a result of an antigenic stimulus. It is also known as adaptive immunity because it represents the host's adaptive response to a specific pathogen or other antigen.
  • Passive immunity, on the other hand, is the resistance transmitted passively to a recipient in a "ready-made" form, where the recipient's immune system plays no active role. Immunoglobulin transfer (e.g., maternal antibodies crossing the placenta, or antitoxin administration) is a classic example of acquiring passive immunity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Infection (Option A): Infection leads to active immunity as the body's immune system is stimulated by the pathogen to produce its own antibodies and memory cells.

Vaccination (Option B): Vaccination induces active immunity by exposing the immune system to antigens (e.g., attenuated or inactivated pathogens, their components, or toxoids) without causing disease, prompting the body to develop its own protective response and memory.

Sub-clinical infection (Option D): A sub-clinical infection, also known as an asymptomatic infection, still involves exposure to an antigen and stimulation of the immune system, leading to the development of active immunity, even though no noticeable symptoms occur.

Key Takeaway:

Active immunity results from the body's own immune response to an antigen (e.g., via infection, vaccination, or sub-clinical infection), while passive immunity is acquired by receiving pre-formed antibodies (e.g., via immunoglobulin transfer), without the recipient's immune system actively participating.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a killed vaccine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Yellow fever vaccine is NOT a killed vaccine; it is a Live attenuated vaccine. It is derived from the 17D strain of the virus, meaning it contains a weakened but living form of the pathogen.
  • This vaccine is administered as a single subcutaneous injection.
  • It is highly effective, providing a protection rate of over 99% in immunocompetent recipients.
  • Immunity typically develops within 10 days after vaccination and is considered lifelong.
  • The vaccine is recommended for people traveling to endemic areas.

Explanation of Other Options:

Salk (Polio) (Option B): The Salk polio vaccine is a killed (inactivated) vaccine, meaning it contains poliovirus that has been chemically inactivated.

Hepatitis B (Option C): The Hepatitis B vaccine is an inactivated vaccine. It is a recombinant subunit vaccine, containing only a non-infectious part of the virus (surface antigen).

Human diploid cell rabies vaccine (Option D): The human diploid cell rabies vaccine is a killed (inactivated) vaccine, containing rabies virus that has been chemically inactivated.

Key Takeaway:

Yellow fever vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, using a weakened form of the virus to induce robust, lifelong immunity, whereas Salk (Polio), Hepatitis B, and Human diploid cell rabies vaccines are all types of killed (inactivated) vaccines.

Types of vaccine:

choices.text: Hepatitis B Vaccine; Live Attenuated Vaccine

questions.text: Choose the correctly matched pair?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PFIZER-BioNTECH COVID 19 is correctly matched with MRNA (Option D). The Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine (also known as BNT162b2) is indeed an mRNA-based vaccine developed by the German biotechnology company BioNTech.

Other vaccines for COVID 19:

  • Covishield: chimpanzee adenovirus adenovirus (Ab against spike antigen)
  • Covaxin: inactivated virion (multiple antibodies)
  • Sputnik: Human adeno virus spike protein.

Explanation of Other Options:

BCG vaccine; Cell fraction derived (Option A): The BCG vaccine is a live attenuated bacterial vaccine, not a cell fraction derived vaccine.

Sabin Polio Vaccine; Inactivated Vaccine (Option B): The Sabin Polio Vaccine is a live attenuated (oral) vaccine, not an inactivated vaccine. The Salk polio vaccine is the inactivated version.

Hepatitis B Vaccine; Live Attenuated Vaccine (Option C): The Hepatitis B Vaccine is an inactivated subunit vaccine (specifically recombinant), not a live attenuated vaccine.

Key Takeaway:

The Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine represents a modern vaccine technology based on mRNA, while other vaccines like Covishield use chimpanzee adenovirus, Covaxin uses inactivated virion, and Sputnik uses human adenovirus.

questions.text: IL-I is produced by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • IL-1 is produced by Macrophages.
  • Cytokines are peptide mediators or intercellular messengers that regulate immunological, inflammatory, and reparative host responses.
  • They are highly potent, hormone-like substances, active even at femtomolar concentrations.
  • Cytokines differ from endocrine hormones as they are produced by widely distributed cells (including lymphocytes, macrophages, platelets, and fibroblasts).
  • They typically act locally near the producing cells (paracrine effect) or directly on the producing cells themselves (autocrine effect).

Explanation of Other Options:

Helper T lymphocytes (Option B): Helper T lymphocytes produce various cytokines to regulate immune responses but are not the primary producers of IL-1.

Natural Killer cells (Option C): Natural Killer cells (NK cells) produce cytokines such as interferon-gamma and are involved in innate immunity, but IL-1 is not their primary cytokine product.

Cytotoxic T-cells (Option D): Cytotoxic T-cells primarily kill infected or cancerous cells and produce molecules like perforin and granzymes, along with some cytokines like interferon-gamma, but not typically IL-1.

Key Takeaway:

Macrophages are key producers of IL-1, an important cytokine that acts as an intercellular messenger regulating immunological, inflammatory, and reparative responses.

questions.text: IL-2 is produced by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • T cells, particularly activated Helper T (T$_H$) cells, are the primary producers of Interleukin-2 (IL-2).
  • IL-2 is a crucial cytokine that acts as a growth factor for T cells, promoting their proliferation and differentiation.
  • It is essential for the clonal expansion of antigen-specific T cells, allowing the immune system to mount a robust response against pathogens.
  • Activated Cytotoxic T cells (CTLs) can also produce IL-2, contributing to their own survival and function.

Explanation of Other Options:

B cells (Option B): B cells are primarily responsible for producing antibodies and acting as antigen-presenting cells, contributing significantly to humoral immunity.

Monocytes (Option C): Monocytes are circulating precursors that differentiate into macrophages in tissues. Macrophages are known for producing pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1 and TNF-alpha, which are crucial for early immune responses.

Neutrophils (Option D): Neutrophils are phagocytic cells that are typically the first responders to infection sites, primarily focusing on engulfing and destroying pathogens.

Key Takeaway:

IL-2 is a critical cytokine primarily produced by activated T cells, acting as a growth factor to drive T cell proliferation and differentiation, which is essential for mounting an effective adaptive immune response.

questions.text: Which leukotriene is the adhesion factor for the neutrophil on the cell surface to attach to endothelium:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Leukotriene B4 is an adhesion factor that contributes to the attachment of neutrophils to the endothelium.
  • LTB4 has a chemotactic effect on migrating neutrophils, helping to guide these cells to the inflamed tissue.
  • Along with Platelet-Activating Factor (PAF), LTB4 can activate rolling leukocytes, which increases the expression and avidity of adhesion molecules like CD11/CD18. This increased avidity is crucial for initiating the transition from rolling to firm adhesion of neutrophils to the endothelial surface.

Explanation of Other Options:

C4 (Option B): Leukotriene C4 is primarily known for its role as a potent bronchoconstrictor and increasing vascular permeability, contributing to the slow-reacting substance of anaphylaxis, rather than directly mediating neutrophil adhesion.

D4 (Option C): Leukotriene D4 is another cysteinyl leukotriene with strong bronchoconstrictor and vascular permeability-increasing effects, similar to LTC4, and is involved in allergic and asthmatic responses. It does not primarily function as a neutrophil adhesion factor.

E4 (Option D): Leukotriene E4 is also a cysteinyl leukotriene that contributes to bronchoconstriction and vascular permeability, often considered a metabolite of LTC4 and LTD4, and is involved in the late phase of allergic reactions. It is not known as an adhesion factor for neutrophils.

Key Takeaway:

Leukotriene B4 (LTB4) plays a critical role in neutrophil recruitment and adhesion by acting as a chemotactic agent and by enhancing the expression and avidity of neutrophil adhesion molecules like CD11/CD18, facilitating their firm attachment to the endothelium.

questions.text: A patient with lepromatous leprosy was administered transfer factor as treatment. What type of immunity does this result in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Administering a transfer factor as treatment, such as in a patient with lepromatous leprosy, results in adoptive immunity.
  • Adoptive immunity is a special type of immunization achieved by injecting immunologically competent lymphocytes.
  • The 'transfer factor' is specifically an extract of these immunologically competent lymphocytes.
  • This approach has been explored in conditions like lepromatous leprosy and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Active immunity (Option A): This is the resistance developed by an individual's own immune system as a result of an antigenic stimulus. It is also known as adaptive immunity, representing the host's adaptive response to a specific pathogen or antigen. Transfer factor administration directly provides immune components, rather than stimulating the recipient's own active response.

Passive immunity (Option B): This is resistance transmitted passively to a recipient in a 'ready-made' form, where the recipient's immune system plays no active role. While transfer factor provides "ready-made" components, adoptive immunity is distinct because it involves the transfer of cells or cell extracts that can proliferate and confer specific cell-mediated immunity, rather than just antibodies as in typical passive immunity.

Combined immunity (Option D): This is not a standard, distinct category of immunity. Immunity types are typically classified as active, passive, or adoptive, referring to how the immune protection is acquired.

Key Takeaway:

Adoptive immunity involves the transfer of immunologically competent lymphocytes or their extracts (like transfer factor) to a recipient, directly conferring cellular immunity, which is distinct from active immunity (self-generated) and passive immunity (pre-formed antibodies).

questions.text: Isotype switching is a process in which the interleukin changes the IgM, IgD into Ig(GAMDE). For this process to happen what are the markers it required?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • For isotype switching to occur, the key markers required are IL-4 and CD40).
  • Isotype switching is a process where B cells change their production of IgM and IgD to other immunoglobulin isotypes such as IgG, IgA, or IgE.
  • This process is critically dependent on the interaction between B cells, which have CD40 receptors, and T cells, which have CD40 Ligands.
  • Following this interaction, T cells release IL-4.
  • This IL-4 then mediates the conversion of IgM and IgD to other Ig classes (IgG, IgA, IgE).

Explanation of Other Options:

IL2 and CD20 (Option A): While CD20 is a B cell marker, IL-2 is primarily involved in T cell proliferation and is not the key interleukin mediating isotype switching.

IL4 and CD20 (Option C): While IL-4 is the correct interleukin for mediating isotype switching, CD40 (and its ligand) is the specific co-stimulatory molecule directly involved in the interaction required for the switch, rather than CD20 directly driving the switch.

IL2 and CD40 (Option D): While CD40 is crucial for the interaction, IL-2 is not the interleukin that directly mediates the conversion of antibody isotypes; IL-4 performs this role.

Key Takeaway:

Isotype switching is a T cell-dependent process for B cells, requiring the crucial interaction between the CD40 receptor on B cells and the CD40 Ligand on T cells, followed by the release of IL-4 from T cells to mediate the change from IgM/IgD production to other immunoglobulin classes like IgG, IgA, or IgE

questions.text: Affinity maturation of B cells is because of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Affinity maturation of B cells is primarily due to Somatic hypermutation (SHM).
  • Somatic hypermutation (SHM) is a process occurring specifically within B cells in the immune system.
  • It involves the introduction of mutations into the DNA of immunoglobulin (antibody) genes.
  • The main goal of SHM is to improve the binding affinity of antibodies to their specific antigens, thereby enhancing the effectiveness of the immune response.
  • After SHM, B cells that produce higher-affinity antibodies are selected for survival and proliferation, while those with lower-affinity variants may undergo apoptosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Isotype switching (Option A): Isotype switching, also known as class switch recombination (CSR), is a process that allows B cells to produce different classes (isotypes) of antibodies (e.g., IgG, IgA, IgE) while maintaining the same antigen specificity. It changes the antibody's effector function but does not directly increase its binding affinity.

Somatic recombination (Option C): Somatic recombination in B cells, also known as V(D)J recombination, is a crucial process that generates the vast diversity of antibodies before antigen encounter. It involves the joining of variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments to form a complete gene encoding a unique antibody variable region, determining antigen specificity.

Alternate RNA splicing (Option D): Alternate RNA splicing allows B cells to produce different forms of antibodies from the same gene, specifically the membrane-bound form (acting as a B cell receptor) and the secreted form (sIg). It also enables the co-expression of IgM and IgD on the surface of naive B cells. This process affects antibody localization and initial expression but does not directly lead to affinity maturation.

Key Takeaway:

Affinity maturation, the process by which antibodies increase their binding strength to antigens, is driven by Somatic hypermutation (SHM), which introduces mutations into antibody genes, followed by the selection of B cells producing higher-affinity antibodies.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct matching pairs are as follows:
    • IL-10 matches with 3. Suppressing immune response.
    • IL-2 matches with 1. T cell growth factor.
    • IL-1 matches with 4. Inducing fever and inflammation.
    • IL-4 matches with 2. Differentiation of naïve T cells into TH2 cells.

Key Takeaway: Each interleukin has a specific and crucial role in immune regulation: IL-10 is an immunosuppressive cytokine, IL-2 promotes T cell growth, IL-1 is a key mediator of fever and inflammation, and IL-4 drives the differentiation of naive T cells into TH2 cells.

choices.text: A and R both are true and R is the correct explanation of A
A and R both are true and R is NOT the correct explanation of A
A is true R is false
A is false R is true

questions.text:
Assertion(A)- Adhesins may account for tissue tropism and loss of adhesins often render strain avirulent.
Reason(R)- Adhesins are made of lipids and are antigenic in nature.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Assertion (A) is true: Adhesins can account for tissue tropism, and the loss of adhesins often renders a bacterial strain avirulent.
    • Adhesion is the initial and crucial event in the pathogenesis of many infections, involving specific reactions between host cell surface receptors and bacterial adhesive structures (ligands).
    • These adhesive structures, known as adhesins, can be organized structures like fimbriae, fibrillae, and pili, or colonization factors.
    • Specific adhesins are responsible for the tissue tropisms and host specificity observed in many pathogens.
    • Adhesins serve as important virulence factors.
  • Reason (R) is false: Adhesins are usually made of protein, not lipids, although they are indeed antigenic in nature.
    • Since adhesins are antigenic, specific immunization with adhesins has been attempted as a method of prophylaxis in some infections.
    • Because the Reason (R) contains a factual inaccuracy (adhesins being made of lipids), the entire statement is false.

Explanation of Other Options:

A and R both are true and R is the correct explanation of A (Option A) : This option is incorrect because Reason (R) contains a false statement regarding the composition of adhesins.

A and R both are true and R is NOT the correct explanation of A(Option B): This option is incorrect because Reason (R) contains a false statement regarding the composition of adhesins.

A is false R is true (Option D): This option is incorrect because Assertion (A) is true, and Reason (R) is false due to the incorrect statement about adhesin composition.

Key Takeaway:

Adhesins are protein-based, antigenic virulence factors that enable bacteria to specifically attach to host tissues, determining tissue tropism and contributing to pathogenicity; their loss can lead to avirulence.

questions.text: HLA gene III codes for all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) is controlled by genes known as HLA genes, which are located on chromosome number 6p.
  • The HLA gene III (Class III MHC) region is responsible for coding a variety of proteins that are structurally distinct from the MHC Class I and Class II molecules.
  • Specifically, the HLA gene III region codes for complement components like C2 and C4, as well as Heat Shock Proteins (Hsp) and Tumor Necrosis Factor alpha (TNF-alpha).
  • HLA-G (Option D) is a non-classical MHC Class I molecule. As such, it is coded for by the HLA Class I region (HLA 1), not the HLA Class III region. Therefore, HLA-G is the correct answer as it is the exception.

Explanation of Other Options:

C2 (Option A): C2 is a component of the complement system, and the HLA gene III region is known to code for complementary proteins, including C2.

C4 (Option B): C4 is another component of the complement system, and the HLA gene III region is known to code for complementary proteins, including C4.

Hsp (Option C): Heat Shock Proteins (Hsp) are indeed coded for by the HLA gene III region.

Key Takeaway:

The HLA Class III region codes for diverse immune-related molecules such as complement components (C2, C4) and heat shock proteins (Hsp), which serve functions distinct from antigen presentation, whereas HLA-G is an MHC Class I molecule involved in immune tolerance.

questions.text: Antigen binding cleft of MHC 1 is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The antigen-binding cleft of a Class I Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC I) molecule is formed by the junction of its Alpha1 and Alpha2 domains.
  • This cleft is crucial for binding and presenting peptide antigens to T cells.
  • MHC I molecules are widely distributed, present in all nucleated cells of the body and platelets, with the notable exceptions of red blood cells (RBCs) and sperm.
  • Once an antigen is presented in this cleft, MHC I molecules interact specifically with CD8 T cells, which are primarily cytotoxic T lymphocytes.

Key Takeaway:

The antigen-binding cleft of MHC Class I molecules is formed by the interaction of their Alpha1 and Alpha2 domains, enabling the presentation of peptides to CD8 T cells.
